The security intuition behind ABCCs is clear: if messages
produced by the application are common in the target envi-
ronment, and if the embedding is done well, then application
messages carrying covert bits ought not to arouse suspicions.
Prior work often supports this intuition with empirical analyses
of similarity between normal application messages and those
carrying covert bits. Yet none provides a proper formal foun-
dation for the design and analysis of ABCCs—i.e., a formal
description of an ABCC as an abstract object (what an ABCC
is), and security notions that make precise the adversarial goals
and attack models (what makes an ABCC secure). The main
goal of this work is to provide such a foundation and to
evaluate prior works with respect to it.
Foundations for ABCCs. Towards this goal, we begin by
formalizing ABCCs as a syntactic primitive. In particular,
an ABCC is a tuple of algorithms Π = (Setup, Embeduser,
Embedwire, Extractwire, Extractuser); Figure 1 shows a block-
diagram of these algorithms in use. Our syntactic choices
were informed by the approaches taken in prior work. Indeed,
we have already given examples of prior ABCC schemes
that embed on the user-side, and others that embed on the
wire-side. Yet we know of no system that takes advantage
of embedding on both the user-side and the wire-side. Even
without considering de novo schemes, it seems plausible that
systems that use the same “type” of application for overt traffic
(e.g., Castle and Rook) could be combined to increase the
overall system throughput. In any case, our syntax explicitly
surfaces this possibility.
Our second foundational contribution is to define a notion
of security for ABCCs. Loosely speaking, this notion says that
the observable traffic produced by an ABCC should look like
that of the co-opted application under normal use. To capture
the latter, we formalize application channels as a tuple of
algorithms App = (Init, Source, Sink), where Source denotes
the initiator (e.g., client) and Sink denotes the responder (e.g.,
server). Given an application channel, our security notion
demands that messages sent from Source to Sink, and the Sink-
responses these trigger (i.e., overt communication), should be
computationally indistinguishable from messages sent from
the Source-side of the covert-channel to the Sink-side of it,
and the Sink-responses that they trigger.

sages should look alike is intuitive, but our notion also makes
explicit the requirement that the observable behaviors of Sink
should not noticeably change when the covert channel is in
operation. This requirement is targeted by Rook, for example,
in identifying mutable fields in game packets, and by Balboa,
by having the server replace covert bits with overt bits before
passing them on to Sink.
Classes of ABCCs and their security. As mentioned, the
ABCCs in prior work can be split into those that process
covert bits by using only Embedwire and Extractwire (effec-
tively fixing Embeduser and Extractuser to be pass-throughs),
and those that process covert bits by using only Embeduser
and Extractuser (i.e., Embedwire and Extractwire are pass-
throughs). The former we call wire-only schemes, and the
latter we call user-only schemes. Within these two classes,
we further distinguish between schemes for which the overt
application-channel messages are protected by a secure chan-
nel, and schemes for which the application channel messages
are sent in the clear. Thus, our work explores four classes of
ABCCs; see Table I for examples of how prior work maps to
these.
In exploring the security of these classes, we identify a
number of crucial non-cryptographic requirements that sys-
tems must meet. For example, consider the class of wire-only
schemes where the overt application messages are protected
by a secure channel. Here, the ABCC must achieve sink-
indistinguishability and shape-preservation, two of the prop-
erties that we introduce. Informally, the former says that the
observable output of Sink should not signal that it has received
messages from Source, directly, or from Extractwire. The latter
says that the “shape” of the outputs (i.e., number and length
of messages) of Embedwire and Source must not distinguish
the two.
Our security notion also explicitly identifies the user-
models that drive the covert (ABCC) and overt (application
channel) communication, something often left implicit in prior
work. Intuitively,
if one has collected traffic in order to
characterize “normal” use of an application, then there is some
implicit “normal user” model that is inducing that traffic. Call
this User0. Likewise, there is some process, User1, that is
driving the ABCC; this may be an explicit user-model (e.g.,
as in Castle), or an implicit model of how an actual human
would—or should—interact with the system. By elevating the
user-model to an explicit parameter of the security experiment,
we are able to surface a non-cryptographic requirement for all
four classes of ABCC systems: that overt application traffic
should not signal whether it is User1 or User0 that is driving
the application. This is somewhat surprising, as it is more
intuitive to compare the ABCC traffic induced by User1 to the
overt application traffic induced by User0. Nonetheless, our
formalization allows us to show that a more constrained notion
of “user indistinguishability” suffices for the constructions
considered in this work.2
One may reasonably wonder what is the benefit in sur-
facing non-cryptographic properties. After all, these cannot
be cryptanalyzed, or reduced to some plausible hardness
assumption. We believe that one important benefit is this: it
makes explicit the minimal properties a secure ABCC needs to
satisfy, even if the cryptographic components are perfect. Our
security results point to specific empirical evaluations, a staple
of security arguments in the literature. Moreover, by describing
these non-cryptographic properties in pseudocode, our abstract
experiments are more easily translated into actual experiments
for system evaluators. To demonstrate the applicability of this
approach, we discuss in §VII-D how two recent systems—
Balboa [6] and Protozoa [8]—map to our framework, and the
necessary empirical analysis our security reductions highlight.
Scoping and Caveats. While we believe our approach will
benefit system developers and enable more principled com-
parisons of one system to another, it is important to make
clear the scope our framework and security results.
We formally analyze abstractions of network-censorship
circumvention systems, and our security results for these
abstractions are not guarantees on the security of a real system
in a real deployment.
Our abstraction elides the particular implementation de-
tails of the application protocol, as well as the specifics of the
netwok over which the application traffic is transmitted. Thus,
attacks based upon (say) differential timing between ABCC
